results.title: Western Europe: an introduction
results.brief_description: An introduction to the basic geographic concepts of eleven countries in west Europe: Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands, Western Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Italy, France, Spain and Portugal. Presents the complexity of various countries and peoples; the dense population, the careful and varied uses of the land in relationship to the climate; the importance of manufacture and trade and also the close link between the history and geography of Europe to the western world.

results.title: Western Australia: the search for oil
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the first operational stage of the search for oil at Exmouth Gulf (WA) including the seismograph party making exploratory drillings and echo soundings with explosives. (Explains the principle of this method with diagrams.) A highlight is the building of the large derrick before drilling for oil began.

results.title: Western Australia's moving memories...
results.creator_credit: Glenda Hambly, Paul D. Barron and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Picnic parties, picture shows and promenading. Festivities, fashions and frontiers. Living in the first half of this century in Western Australia had an elegance even in the hardships of its isolation and pioneer lifestyle. Watch Perth grow into a capital city and centre of commerce. Its streets and suburbs flourishing around the Swan River. Travel to rural centres where the whole community gathers to watch a race and to its frontier towns where gold is the currency of life and death. See everyday life as sheep are dipped, cattle are paraded at the Agricultural Show, and people picnic at the zoo, frolic on the beaches and run errands down the street. Made up of rare archival footage from Western Australian sources and from the National Film and Sound Archive this fascinating video includes newsreels, documentaries, and actuality footage from 1902 to 1952.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Glenda Hambly, Paul D. Barron and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: West of Pinto Basin. Part II
results.creator_credit: Roy Luby, George Weeks and Peak Films
results.brief_description: Part two of a two-part story. The Range Busters solve the mystery of a series of stage-coach robberies. Pleasant, light western. Suitable for children. Cast includes John King, Ray Corrigan. Silent film with English captions.

results.title: West of England
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Swingler, Paul Fletcher and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: A picture of the Stroud Valley in Western England where weaving is still the principal industry even as it was hundreds of years ago. The sheep that once grazed there are now gone, and wool is imported from Australia, but rushing streams still provide water power and the weavers still produce fine cloth and maintain pride in their ancient craft.

results.title: West Germany: industrial giant
results.brief_description: Covers the regions of Western Germany and the character of the people in the various areas of the country. Surveys the heavy industries of the Ruhr Valley and the craft industries spread throughout the rural areas. We see the mountains, the Rhine, Munich, Hamburg and Bonn.

results.title: West country journey
results.creator_credit: Syd Sharples, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Shows examples of scenery and features which give the counties of Devon and Cornwall their attractive character. Includes the multi-colored pattern of the Devon countryside; the rivers, moors, old historic buildings at Totnes, Dartmouth and Exeter; tiny ports and naval docks at Devonport and the long sandy beaches of Cornwall. Photography by Ronald Craigen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Syd Sharples, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: Welfare of the workers
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings, GPO Film Unit and Great Britain. Ministry of Information
results.brief_description: Shows efforts by the British government to maintain production during the war. Many working men and women were required to relocate to factories away from their home town to support the changing production demands of war. Recognising that the health, safety and welfare of workers was critical to victory, various programs were implemented to assist relocated workers. These varied from locating suitable accommodation, providing health services and ensuring that recreational activities were available to workers during their leisure time. New lighting and ventilation designs were also introduced into factories to compensate for the conditions caused by the blackouts that were enforced during aerial attacks.
